So does that mean if I were an ET or man-in-black and had control of a stat=
ion like Trans World Radio I could cover much of the planet with=A0my signa=
l?=A0=A0 Maybe even receive communications if someone scanned through?=A0 r=
on

--- On Wed, 11/19/08, Zack Widup <w9sz@...> wrote:

From: Za=
ck Widup <w9sz@...>
Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: 1485 kHz
To: EVP-=
ITC@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wednesday, November 19, 2008, 10:29 PM







Whe=
n I got my Novice license in 1967 I mainly hung out on 40 and 15 
meters. D=
idn't have an antenna that worked on 80 meters (or so I 
thought). I've sin=
ce learned that any piece of wire can be tuned to 80 
meters and some of th=
em actually radiate!
:-)

I'm curious about this 1485 kHz frequency. And I =
was surprised the FCC 
website I listed would come up with so many foreign =
stations on 1480 and 
1490. Lots of interesting data from that website. Tra=
ns World Radio in 
Bonaire on 800 kHz runs 500 kW - that's half a million w=
atts!

Zack (W9SZ)

On Thu, 20 Nov 2008, threadsintyme@ juno.com wrote:

> =
Zack,
> You're quite right...I was thinking of 15 meters. Hung out on 20 an=
d 40 meters respectively.
> Al
>
> -- Zack Widup <w9sz@prairienet. org> wro=
te:
>
>
> Hi Al,
>
> Do you mean the 14 MHz (20 meter) band or 21 MHz (15 m=
eter) band? 14
> meters was never allocated to radio amateurs. :-)
>
> Unti=
l we get some more sunspots, 15 meters and above has been fairly dead
> for=
 over a year. 20 meters has quite a bit of activity and 40 and 80
> meters =
get most of the activity these days.
>
> 1485 kHz is in the AM broadcast ba=
nd but isn't a standard channel in the
> USA, which goes in 10 kHz steps. T=
here would be stations on 1480 and 1490
> in the USA, not necesssarily in y=
our area, though. If you go to this page:
>
> http://www.fcc. gov/mb/audio/=
 amq.html
>
> Enter 1480 as the lower frequency and 1490 as the upper frequ=
ency and
> you'll get a page listing all the stations on those two frequenc=
ies.
>
> Zack
>
> On Wed, 19 Nov 2008, threadsintyme@ juno.com wrote:
>
>> =
LOL...Same here! I *thought* that this sounded as if it were in the AM band=
.
>> Glad I didn't ask if it was AM or FM or SSB! LOL hehe
>> Man, I rememb=
er when I was a kid and would work DX on the 14 meter band. CW was my choic=
e and really loved it. <sigh, heavy, heart broken sigh>
>> That was back in=
 the good ole daze of 1968...had more sick days at school that they kept up=
 with!
>> Al
>>
>> -- don powell <dpowell7299@ yahoo.com> wrote:
>>
>> Acco=
rding to Wikipedia, 1485 Khz is in the AM band region. I had thought so but=
 had to look it up.... really long time since my radio/antenna design days =
:)
>>
>> Don
>>

om

r what is on that frequency in the US?
>> Al
>>
>> -- "Jeff" <vortex6066@ y=
ahoo. com.au> wrote:
>>
>> Hi Mike,
>> My viewpoint on this is that 1485kHz=
 was a frequency that provided
>> Jurgenson with one (of probably many) cor=
rect combinations of
>> frequency spectra and dynamics necessary for the fo=
rmation of EVP -
>> at that period in time, and at that location.
>> In cha=
pter 24 of "Sprechfunk mit Verstorbenen" , Jurgenson mentions
>> that "Lena=
" used a special sound frequency that she fashioned from
>> the overlapping=
 of certain sounds and which would have sounded in
>> most cases like a ton=
eless, meaningless hissing.
>> Also he mentions that the "friends" were abl=
e to shape the sound
>> frequencies of the radio waves by instantly modulat=
ing the existing
>> sounds.
>> But most importantly, in chapter 43 he menti=
ons being able to turn
>> the radio dial carefully and hear Lena's voice on=
 almost every
>> frequency.
>>
>> I tend to conclude therefore that 1485khz=
 was one of many useful
>> frequencies he used that time, but probably hold=
s no specific
>> relevance today, excepting if it is able to provide the co=
rrect
>> spectral dynamics (more than any other frequency).
>> regards,
>> =
JEFF
